questions.text: A 31-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of weakness. Two days ago, the patient’s legs felt heavy, which was attributed to exercise. This morning, the weakness worsened, and the patient started tripping on the stairs. A review of systems reveals recent gastrointestinal symptoms, including diarrhea and abdominal cramping. The patient feels unable to catch his breath. There is no significant past medical history, and no daily medication is taken. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 120/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. There is symmetric bilateral weakness with ankle dorsiflexion and knee flexion and extension, as well as a loss of vibration sense. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the bilateral lower extremities. Which of the following laboratory study results is most likely to be associated with this patient’s diagnosis?

choices.text: Elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) white blood cell count
Elevated serum very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) level

questions.solution:
This patient presents with rapidly progressive ascending weakness and areflexia after a recent gastrointestinal illness, suggesting Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS), an acquired polyneuropathy. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) testing typically shows albuminocytologic dissociation, with an elevated protein level and normal white blood cell count.

Polyneuropathies are associated with demyelination or axonal injury of multiple peripheral nerves. Etiologies can be hereditary or acquired, and the differential diagnosis can often be narrowed by the family history or the timing of symptom progression. Acquired polyneuropathies with acute presentations include GBS and critical illness polyneuropathy, while those with more chronic, progressive presentations include vitamin B12 deficiency, as well as diabetic and alcoholic neuropathies.

Genetic testing is available to distinguish between Friedrich ataxia, which is associated with trinucleotide repeat expansions in the frataxin gene, adrenomyeloneuropathy, which is associated with mutations in the ABCD1 gene, and Charcot-Marie-Tooth type 1a, which is associated with duplication of the PMP22 gene. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis (e.g. albuminocytologic dissociation in GBS) or serum laboratory analyses (e.g. vitamin B12 level) can be helpful in distinguishing between the various acquired causes of polyneuropathy.

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) protein level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) white blood cell count:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms of rapidly progressive polyneuropathy following a recent gastrointestinal illness suggest Guillain-Barre syndrome, which is associated with albuminocytologic disassociation. In this condition, the CSF protein level is elevated, while the white blood cell count remains normal.
❌ Decreased serum vitamin B12 level:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms of rapidly progressive polyneuropathy following a recent gastrointestinal illness suggest Guillain-Barre syndrome, which is associated with an elevated CSF protein level. Polyneuropathy due to vitamin B12 deficiency is typically slowly progressive and presents with sensory symptoms such as numbness or tingling.
❌ Elevated serum hemoglobin A1c level:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms of rapidly progressive polyneuropathy following a recent gastrointestinal illness suggest Guillain-Barre syndrome, which is associated with an elevated CSF protein level. Diabetic polyneuropathy is a slowly progressive condition associated with long-standing poor glucose control.
❌ Elevated serum very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) level:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms of rapidly progressive polyneuropathy following a recent gastrointestinal illness suggest Guillain-Barre syndrome, which is associated with an elevated CSF protein level. Adrenomyeloneuropathy, which is associated with elevated VLCFA levels, typically presents as a slowly progressive polyneuropathy.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a three-week history of frequent severe, throbbing headaches on the left side of his head. He also reports feeling fatigued and has experienced a 6 lb (2.7 kg) unintentional weight loss over the past month. He says he feels weak and tired in the mornings and cannot raise his arms to brush his hair. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation in the left temporal region of the head. Laboratory findings are significant for a markedly elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Which of the following physical examination findings is most likely to be seen in this patient given the likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with unilateral headaches in association with weight loss and fatigue as well as an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) most likely has temporal arteritis. Furthermore, the patient has symptoms suggestive of polymyalgia rheumatica (e.g. morning stiffness, proximal muscle weakness): a diagnosis frequently associated with temporal arteritis.    

Temporal arteritis, also known as giant cell arteritis, is an inflammatory vasculitis of medium and large arteries. In temporal arteritis, there is inflammation and thickening of the vessel wall, which eventually can result in ischemia and complications, such as vision loss. As the name suggests, the temporal artery is the most common vessel involved; however, intracranial and extracranial vessels can be affected as well, especially the vertebrobasilar arterial system. More remote sites of vascular involvement include the aorta and its proximal branches, like the carotid, subclavian, axillary, and brachial arteries.  

The greatest risk factor for developing temporal arteritis is aging. The disease almost never occurs before the age of 50, and its incidence rises steadily thereafter. It peaks between the ages of 70 to 79 with over 80 percent of patients older than 70 years of age. Patients typically report a new-onset localized headache, described as unilateral pain in the temporal region that worsens over time. These symptoms are often associated with scalp pain and tenderness as well as systemic symptoms like fatigue, malaise, fever, and unintentional weight loss. In more severe cases, patients may notice symptoms suggestive of ischemia, including sudden vision changes ranging from diplopia to complete vision loss. There may also be pain with chewing, known as jaw claudication. Patients may have signs and symptoms of polymyalgia rheumatica, including neck, shoulder, and hip pain and stiffness.  

Physical examination may reveal abnormalities in the temporal artery, including tenderness, ropiness, nodularity, and altered pulse quality due to occlusive vasculitis occuring within the vessel, while fundoscopic examination can reveal optic disc pallor and edema. If the vessels of the ophthalmic artery are affected, patients will present with visual symptoms, such as amaurosis fugax. Laboratory values are nonspecific but will often reveal signs of systemic inflammation like elevated inflammatory markers (e.g. ESR, CRP), thrombocytosis, and normocytic anemia. Diagnosis is confirmed with biopsy showing transmural inflammation, multinucleated giant cells, and mononuclear infiltrate.



Option Analysis

❌ Proptosis:
Incorrect: Proptosis, or bulging of the eyes, is not typically associated with temporal arteritis. Proptosis may be seen in patients with Graves' ophthalmopathy or thyroid eye disease. Vision loss can be seen in temporal arteritis and results from arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION).
❌ Absent corneal reflex:
Incorrect: Absent corneal reflex refers to the lack of a response when the cornea is touched, indicating damage to the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V). This patient’s presentation is classic for temporal arteritis, which can cause severe headaches and visual disturbances due to involvement of the arteries supplying the optic nerve, but it does not directly affect the corneal reflex. 
❌ Bounding left temporal artery pulse:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is classic for temporal arteritis, which typically presents with decreased or absent pulses in the temporal arteries, not increased pulses. 
✅ Enlarged left temporal artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nuchal rigidity:
Incorrect: Nuchal rigidity is a physical examination finding associated with meningitis. Meningitis typically presents more acutely (over a span of days) as opposed to this patient’s subacute presentation of several weeks. Furthermore, patients typically present with fevers and other historical findings (e.g. photophobia).

questions.text:
A 69-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a history of frequent severe, throbbing headaches on the right side. She also describes a recent episode of sudden vision loss in her right eye. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation of bilateral temporal regions of her head with decreased temporal artery pulsation on the right. Fundoscopic examination reveals swelling and pallor of the optic disc in the right eye. Laboratory findings are shown below. Ophthalmology is consulted. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

 Laboratory value  Result 
 White blood cell count  11,500/mm3 
 Hemoglobin  11.5 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume  88 μm3 
 Platelet count  510,000/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  80 mm/h 
 C-reactive protein  25 mg/L

choices.text: Surgical revascularization of the affected artery
Neurosurgical consultation for optic nerve decompression
Confirmation of the diagnosis with biopsy prior to starting corticosteroids
Initiation of antiplatelet therapy to improve blood flow

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe, throbbing right-sided headaches; sudden vision loss in the right eye; and tenderness of bilateral temporal regions with decreased temporal artery pulsation on the right side. She also has pallor of the optic disc, which indicates temporal arteritis with vision changes.    

Temporal arteritis, also known as giant cell arteritis, is an inflammatory vasculitis of medium and large arteries; which eventually can result in ischemia and complications, such as vision loss.   

In cases of suspected temporal arteritis, especially when associated with visual symptoms, prompt treatment is crucial to prevent irreversible complications, such as ischemic optic neuropathy and permanent blindness. High-dose corticosteroids, such as prednisone, are the mainstay of treatment as they effectively suppress the inflammatory process in the temporal arteries, reducing the risk of vascular complications. Initiating intravenous corticosteroid therapy promptly is essential to mitigate inflammation, preserve vision, and prevent further visual impairment in patients with temporal arteritis and visual changes. These patients should also have an urgent ophthalmology consult.    

Patients presenting with temporal arteritis without visual symptoms can be started on oral steroids, typically prednisone. An outpatient ophthalmology consultation should be scheduled as soon as possible to assess the optic nerve. In either case, it is crucial to start steroids early to prevent complications.    

Diagnostic confirmation is done with a temporal artery biopsy, ideally performed within 2 to 4 weeks of initiating steroids, as early treatment can alter biopsy findings. Biopsy classically reveals transmural inflammation with multinucleated giant cells, mononuclear infiltrate, and disruption of the internal elastic lamina in affected arteries. However, false negative rates with biopsy are high, due to the discontinuous character of the histopathologic changes (skip lesions) and the fact that glucocorticoid treatment may reduce the sensitivity of temporal artery biopsy. Therefore, if clinical suspicion remains high despite a negative biopsy, a contralateral biopsy can be performed; or imaging, such as a color duplex ultrasound of the temporal artery or an MRI with contrast of the cranial vessels, may be helpful for establishing a diagnosis.    

Lastly, all patients should have a rheumatology consult to determine if steroid-sparing agents, such as an interleukin-6 inhibitor (e.g. tocilizumab), or a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (e.g. methotrexate or abatacept) should be added.  



Option Analysis

✅ Immediate initiation of high-dose corticosteroids :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Surgical revascularization of the affected artery:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is characteristic of severe temporal arteritis, for which the primary treatment is high-dose corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and prevent complications, particularly visual impairment due to ischemic optic neuropathy. Surgical revascularization of the affected temporal artery is not recommended treatment for temporal arteritis.
❌ Neurosurgical consultation for optic nerve decompression:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is characteristic of severe temporal arteritis. Optic nerve decompression is not a primary or established intervention for temporal arteritis and does not address the underlying inflammatory process in the temporal arteries.
❌ Confirmation of the diagnosis with biopsy prior to starting corticosteroids:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is characteristic of severe temporal arteritis, which, especially in cases with visual symptoms, requires urgent intervention to prevent irreversible complications like permanent blindness. Delaying treatment with glucocorticoids to confirm the diagnosis can lead to progressive damage of the optic nerve and is not recommended. Biopsy can be performed within two weeks of starting glucocorticoids. 
❌ Initiation of antiplatelet therapy to improve blood flow:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is characteristic of temporal arteritis, which is primarily an inflammatory disorder. Therefore, the mainstay of treatment is high-dose corticosteroids to suppress inflammation and prevent complications, especially visual impairment due to ischemic optic neuropathy. Antiplatelet therapy can be added to prevent cardiovascular events, but it does not address the underlying inflammatory process.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a history of frequent severe, throbbing headaches on the right. She also has severe jaw pain on the right when chewing food, which is relieved when she stops eating. She has not had any visual symptoms. Past medical history is significant for osteoporosis for which she takes alendronate daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation of the temporal regions of her head bilaterally with decreased pulsation. Fundoscopic examination is within normal limits. Laboratory findings are shown below. A biopsy to confirm the diagnosis is scheduled. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

 Laboratory value  Result 
 White blood cell count  11,500/mm3 
 Hemoglobin  10.5 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume  81 μm3 
 Platelet count  520,000/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  86 mm/h 
 C-reactive protein  35 mg/L
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with severe, throbbing headaches; jaw claudication; tenderness of the bilateral temporal regions with decreased pulses bilaterally; and signs of systemic inflammation (e.g. elevated ESR and CRP, thrombocytosis) most likely has temporal arteritis.    

Treatment of GCA without visual symptoms involves high-dose oral prednisone. Oral glucocorticoids are continued at high doses until acute symptoms resolve, and then they are gradually tapered off over at least a few months. For patients with newly diagnosed GCA who are at increased risk of glucocorticoid-related adverse effects, tocilizumab should be added to glucocorticoid therapy. Patients who are at increased risk of developing glucocorticoid-related side effects or complications include those with osteoporosis, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, or glaucoma. Methotrexate may be used as an alternative to tocilizumab for patients who are unable to take tocilizumab due to factors such as availability, cost, recurrent infections, or a history of gastrointestinal perforations or diverticulitis. Rheumatology should be consulted to guide management. For patients who have involvement of the cerebral or carotid arteries, low-dose aspirin is added to the regimen for the prevention of ischemic events (i.e. stroke).  

Patients should also receive adjunctive therapy to mitigate corticosteroid-related complications. Bisphosphonates, such as alendronate, and calcium/vitamin D supplements are often prescribed to mitigate the risk of osteoporosis. Additionally, proton pump inhibitors may be considered for gastrointestinal protection due to the increased risk of ulcer formation. Regular follow-up appointments are crucial to monitor the patient's response to treatment, adjust the corticosteroid tapering schedule, and assess for potential complications or relapses.


Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous corticosteroids:
Incorrect: For all patients with giant cell arteritis (GCA), the initial treatment is with high-dose systemic glucocorticoids. Intravenous steroids are used in cases where there is transient or permanent visual loss. This patient has no history of visual disturbances; therefore, she does not currently require intravenous steroids. Given her history of osteoporosis, oral prednisone in combination with tocilizumab should be started.
❌ Oral prednisone:
Incorrect: For patients with newly diagnosed GCA with an increased risk of glucocorticoid-related adverse effects, such as in patients with osteoporosis, tocilizumab should be added to glucocorticoid therapy. This patient should be started on the glucocorticoid-sparing agent tocilizumab in addition to oral prednisone. 
❌ Aspirin :
Incorrect: Temporal arteritis is primarily an inflammatory disorder affecting medium and large arteries, and the mainstay of treatment involves high-dose corticosteroids to suppress the inflammation. Antiplatelet therapy alone does not address the underlying inflammatory process. Given her history of osteoporosis, oral prednisone in combination with tocilizumab should be started.
✅ Oral prednisone and tocilizumab :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Methotrexate :
Incorrect: Methotrexate may be used as an alternative to tocilizumab in combination with steroids for patients who are unable to take tocilizumab due to cost, availability, or risk of potential side effects. However, it would not be used alone in the treatment of GCA.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a headache and vomiting which started 2 hours ago. The headache is pulsating and worse with physical activity. Noises sound louder than usual and make the headache worse. She has vomited twice since the onset of the headache. She has had six similar episodes in the last year, usually around the onset of her menstrual period. The patient has no chronic medical conditions and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mmHg. On examination, the patient appears to be in pain. There is no abdominal tenderness. Cranial nerves II-XII are grossly intact and the rest of the neurologic exam is nonfocal. Which of the following sets of additional findings would most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with recurrent episodes of vomiting, phonophobia, and headache that typically occur around her menstrual cycle, likely has migraine headaches. Migraine can be diagnosed clinically when patients have recurrent headaches with classic migraine features that may include unilateral location of the pain, photophobia, and aura symptoms such as visual changes.

The diagnostic workup in patients with chronic vomiting varies depending on the most likely underlying cause of the symptoms. The first step in evaluating patients with chronic vomiting is to determine whether it is likely from an abdominal or non-abdominal cause. Patients who do not have bowel changes, abdominal pain, or abdominal tenderness with their vomiting are likely to have a non-abdominal cause, such as a neurologic condition, adrenal insufficiency, or renal failure. Symptoms that indicate a possible neurologic cause include headaches, which are seen with increased intracranial pressure and migraine, as well as dizziness which is suggestive of a vestibular cause. Brain imaging should be considered when a neurologic condition is suspected that cannot be confirmed clinically, or when red flag symptoms are present.
   

Option Analysis

✅  Unilateral headache     Photophobia     Visual changes    :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Thunderclap headache     Hyponatremia     Orthostatic hypotension    :
Incorrect: A thunderclap headache is concerning for a subarachnoid hemorrhage, whereas this patient’s symptoms are more consistent with migraine. Hyponatremia and orthostatic hypotension can be seen with adrenal insufficiency but are not typically seen with migraine headaches.  
❌  Previous headaches lasting 7 days     Positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver     Generalized headache    :
Incorrect: This patient has historical and clinical findings that are consistent with a migraine headache; migraines typically last 4 to 72 hours and are unilateral. A positive Dix-Hallpike would suggest benign paroxysmal positional vertigo or other vestibular cause of vomiting. 
❌  Weight loss     Hyperpigmented skin     Papilledema    :
Incorrect: Weight loss and hyperpigmentation of the skin can be seen in adrenal insufficiency; this patient’s vomiting is likely caused by migraine headaches.  Papilledema is seen with increased intracranial pressure, which is not likely the cause of vomiting and headaches in this patient. 
❌  Electrolyte disturbances     Peripheral edema     Muscle cramps    :
Incorrect: Electrolyte disturbances, peripheral edema, and muscle cramps can be seen in patients with renal failure which may lead to vomiting; however, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with migraine headaches.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to debilitating headaches for the past two months. She recently started college, and has been under a lot of stress due to the amount of work. Her medical history is significant for generalized anxiety disorder. She rates the pain as a 5 on a 10-point scale, and describes it as “tightness around her head”. Physical examination shows tenderness over the trapezius muscles bilaterally. Which of the following is most likely to benefit this patient in the long term?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has a tension headache based on her moderate-intensity headache and shoulder muscle tenderness without other symptoms, in association with recent stress and general anxiety disorder.  

The typical presentation of a tension headache includes a bilateral, mild to moderate intensity, non-throbbing headache without other associated features. The pain is often described as “pressure-like” or “band-like,” and patients often have pericranial muscle tenderness. The pathophysiology is uncertain, but proposed mechanisms include peripheral activation or sensitization of myofascial nociceptors. Common precipitating factors are stress and muscle tension. Acute abortive treatment includes non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and acetaminophen, with prophylactic treatment options including behavioral therapy and tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) (e.g. amitriptyline).    

Behavioral therapy for tension headaches includes any of the following:   
  •  Regulation of sleep, exercise, and meals 
  •  Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) 
  •  Relaxation 
  •  Biofeedback 
CBT is aimed to modify maladaptive responses to stressful experiences by altering associated thoughts and assumptions. Identifying headache triggers (e.g., physical, psychological, or behavioral) and developing effective coping strategies are cardinal aspects of therapy. TCAs and CBT may be used together as prophylactic treatment.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Non-steroidal anti-inflammatories:
Incorrect: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are used as an acute abortive treatment for tension headaches, but they are not indicated for prophylaxis. NSAIDs work through the inhibition of cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and/or COX-2), which are involved in the synthesis of biological inflammatory mediators (prostaglandins), thus reducing inflammation.   
✅ Cognitive behavioral therapy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Verapamil:
Incorrect: Verapamil is used as a prophylactic treatment for cluster headaches, but it is not indicated as prophylactic treatment for tension headaches. Verapamil works by blocking voltage-dependent calcium channels found at the sinoatrial and atrioventricular nodes and smooth-muscle lining blood vessels. Blocking these channels leads to vasodilation and reduction of the heart rate.   
❌ Botulinum toxin injections:
Incorrect: Botulinum toxin injections are used as part of the prophylactic regimen for migraine headaches, and they are not indicated for tension headaches. Botulinum toxin works by cleaving SNARE protein, which mediates acetylcholine vesicle fusion and release from the presynaptic vesicle. This stops nerve signaling, leading to paralysis.  
❌ Dihydroergotamine:
Incorrect: Dihydroergotamine can be used as an abortive treatment for migraine headaches. It works through multiple mechanisms including activation of 5-HT1D receptors located on intracranial blood vessels causing vasoconstriction, and/or activation of 5-HT1D receptors on sensory nerve endings of the trigeminal system leading to the inhibition of pro-inflammatory mediator release.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe facial pain. He describes the pain as severe, sharp pain around his right eye and temple. The pain came on slowly two hours ago, and it has been getting worse. He also complains that his right ear feels "full of cotton," and his nose is running. Similar episodes have happened to him over the last few years, often occurring multiple days in a row around the same month. Which of the following would be the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Cluster headaches are a type of primary headache characterized by unilateral pain around the periorbital region, and they are often described to be excruciating in quality. They often occur episodically at the same time of the day (and may occur multiple times per day), with cluster headache cycles usually occurring around the same time of the year. Autonomic symptoms are often associated with cluster headaches ipsilateral to the side of the pain, and only occur during the headache episode. These symptoms include conjunctival injection, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, and nasal congestion. Cluster headaches may also present with ipsilateral Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis).  

The first line treatment for cluster headaches is always 100% oxygen because of its efficacy with lack of side effects. If oxygen fails to reduce symptoms, triptans are the next line of therapy. Triptans are serotonin (5-HT1B/1D) agonists, and may cause adverse effects including coronary artery vasospasm, mild paresthesias, and serotonin syndrome (in combination with other 5-HT agonists). For patients with chronic cluster headaches, verapamil may be used as headache prophylaxis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Carbamazepine :
Incorrect: Carbamazepine is a neuroleptic medication used to treat seizures, neuropathic pain, and bipolar disorder. It is the first line treatment for trigeminal neuralgia, which typically presents with episodic, unilateral, shooting, and “shock like” pain in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). Symptoms are often precipitated by innocuous stimuli (e.g., brushing teeth, shaving, chewing) within the affected trigeminal nerve branch distribution. Carbamazepine has no role in the treatment of cluster headache.   
❌ Ketorolac:
Incorrect: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications, like ketorolac, have a role in the treatment of migraine headaches, but they are not routinely used in the treatment of cluster headaches.  
✅ High-flow nasal cannula:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Amitriptyline:
Incorrect: Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant that is often used in treating peripheral neuropathy, chronic pain, resistant depression as well as migraine or tension headache prophylaxis. However, it is not used for migraines during the acute phase, and it is not indicated for cluster headaches.   
❌ Verapamil:
Incorrect: Verapamil has been shown to be effective for prophylaxis, significantly reducing the attack frequency. It is typically used in patients who have chronic cluster headaches.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the office to evaluate a recurrent right-sided throbbing headache for the past several years. The headache is accompanied by nausea and bright spots in her visual field. The headache usually subsides with rest in a dark, quiet room. The patient does not develop weakness, numbness, or tingling during these episodes. The patient has tried multiple over-the-counter medications without relief. Her past medical history is significant for acne, for which she uses topical tretinoin. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate prophylactic therapy for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features consistent with migraine headaches. Patients with multiple migraines each year often benefit from prophylactic treatment–suitable options include beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol and nadolol), calcium channel blockers (e.g. verapamil), tricyclic antidepressants (e.g. amitriptyline) and anti-epileptic medications (e.g., topiramate and valproate).

OnabotulinumtoxinA, also known as Botox, has proved useful as a prophylactic treatment. This medication is injected into the muscles of the head and neck, where it blocks neurotransmitter release from the trigeminal sensory nerve and subsequent inhibition of painful stimuli. Anti-CGRP antibodies (e.g., erenumab and galcanezumab) block the calcitonin gene-related peptide or its receptor,  and are also effective for prophylaxis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Sumatriptan:
Incorrect: Sumatriptan is a 5-HT1B and 5HT1D serotonin receptor agonist and is the first-line abortive therapy for acute migraine episodes. It is not effective as a preventive therapy.  
✅ Topiramate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dihydroergotamine:
Incorrect: Ergotamine is a 5-HT serotonin receptor agonist used as abortive therapy during migraine episodes. It is not effective as a preventive therapy.  
❌ Metoclopramide:
Incorrect: Metoclopramide is an antiemetic used during migraine attacks associated with nausea and vomiting. It is not effective as a preventive therapy.  
❌ Haloperidol:
Incorrect:  Antipsychotic medications such as haloperidol are D2 receptor antagonists and are typically used to manage schizophrenia, psychosis, and bipolar disorder. It is not a practical option for migraine prophylaxis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of blurry vision. She describes intermittent, transient blurry vision with bending over for the last two weeks, and for the last three days the blurry vision has become constant. Past medical history includes chronic headaches for the past 6 months that have become more intense recently. Medications include an oral contraceptive pill. Temperature is 36.7°C (97.7°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/80. BMI is 23 kg/m2. Visual acuity is 20/60 in both eyes. On examination, she has bilateral concentric visual field loss and impaired abduction bilaterally with lateral gaze. She has no nuchal rigidity and no focal neurologic abnormalities. Which of the following additional findings would most likely be present upon further evaluation?

choices.text: Stenosis of the transverse venous sinuses on brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure of 18 centimeters of water (cmH20).
Meningeal enhancement on brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)

questions.solution:
This patient has fulminant idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) given the rapid progression of symptoms with evidence of severe vision loss. She should have immediate brain MRI with venography. Stenosis of the transverse venous sinuses may be seen on brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in patients with IIH.       

For patients with a history of symptoms of increased intracranial pressure and supportive examination findings, the first step is to obtain neuroimaging with a brain MRI with venography. Radiographic findings suggestive of IIH include an empty sella turcica, posterior globe flattening, dilation of the optic nerve sheaths, stenosis of the transverse venous sinuses, and slit-like ventricles, though neuroimaging may be unremarkable. A lumbar puncture with elevated opening pressure with normal cerebrospinal fluid composition can confirm the diagnosis.        

Once a diagnosis of IIH is suspected, the next step in the evaluation is to assess if an immediate threat of vision loss is present, which will help distinguish between typical and fulminant IIH. Most patients have slowly progressive disease, but a subset of patients have a more malignant course with rapid vision loss developing within weeks of symptom onset. If there has been less than 4 weeks between symptom onset and severe vision loss, or if rapid vision loss has occurred over a few days, then an immediate threat to vision is present, representing fulminant IIH.  If both features are absent, the patient has typical IIH.        

Patients with fulminant disease need immediate brain imaging and treatment with the carbonic anhydrase inhibitor acetazolamide in addition to temporizing treatments. They should also have consultations to determine if more invasive treatments are needed to prevent permanent vision loss.   

Option Analysis

✅ Stenosis of the transverse venous sinuses on brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure of 18 centimeters of water (cmH20).:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of intracranial hypertension. An elevated CSF opening pressure of at least 25 cmH20 is typically seen with this condition.  
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pleocytosis:
Incorrect: This patient is afebrile without nuchal rigidity, making meningitis which is associated with CSF pleocytosis unlikely. With idiopathic intracranial hypertension, CSF analysis reveals a normal composition. 
❌ Meningeal enhancement on brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Incorrect: This patient is afebrile without nuchal rigidity, making meningitis, which is typically associated with radiographic enhancement, unlikely. Brain MRI in patients with Idiopathic intracranial hypertension may show radiographic features such as posterior globe flattening or dilation of the optic nerve sheaths or Stenosis of the transverse venous sinuses on brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). 
❌ Use of topiramate:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of intracranial hypertension. If this patient was prescribed Topiramate as a migraine preventative agent, decreased cerebrospinal fluid production would be expected, rather than the signs of increased CSF pressure present in this patient.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of a worsening headache for the past week. One month ago, she developed a holocephalic headache, that was worse with coughing and sneezing, and she had blurry vision. Fundoscopy at that time revealed bilateral papilledema. Visual field-testing showed an enlarged blind spot bilaterally. Brain magnetic resonance imaging was normal. She was prescribed acetazolamide at that time. She stopped taking her acetazolamide two weeks ago because she developed paresthesia, altered taste, and nausea. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/76. BMI is 30 kg/m2. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral disc elevation and blurred optic disc margins which are stable compared to previous ones, and visual field-testing is unchanged with an enlarged blind spot seen bilaterally. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. In addition to weight reduction efforts and headache management, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has typical idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) without immediate risk of vision loss given that the progression of her symptoms has been slow, and she has no vision loss. She is having significant side effects from acetazolamide, therefore, the next best step in management is a trial of topiramate.        

Treatment of typical IIH includes weight reduction measures, headache management, and use of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, typically acetazolamide. For patients who cannot tolerate acetazolamide due to side effects, a trial of topiramate should be considered as an alternative before pursuing surgical interventions. After treatment initiation, patient response should be routinely assessed by monitoring visual acuity, papilledema severity, and visual field function. If there is evidence of clinical deterioration despite medical management, surgical options including bariatric surgery, optic nerve sheath fenestration, or cerebrospinal fluid diversion procedures should be considered.    

Option Analysis

✅ Topiramate:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Optic nerve sheath fenestration:
Incorrect: Optic nerve sheath fenestration can be considered for patients with fulminant idiopathic intracranial hypertension who do not respond to weight reduction, headache management, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors. This patient presents with typical rather than fulminant disease and should explore other conservative, non-surgical interventions like topiramate first. 
❌ Ventriculoperitoneal shunt placement:
Incorrect: Cerebrospinal fluid diversion via placement of a ventriculoperitoneal shunt can be considered for patients with fulminant idiopathic intracranial hypertension who do not respond to weight reduction, headache management, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors. This patient presents with typical rather than fulminant disease and should explore other conservative, non-surgical interventions like topiramate first. 
❌ Serial lumbar punctures :
Incorrect: Repeated cerebrospinal fluid drainage can be considered for patients with fulminant idiopathic intracranial hypertension who do not respond to weight reduction, headache management, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors. This patient presents with typical rather than fulminant disease and should explore other conservative, non-surgical interventions like topiramate first. 
❌ Bariatric surgery:
Incorrect: While weight reduction efforts, including bariatric surgery, if indicated, are an important part of the evidence-based approach to treatment of idiopathic intracranial hypertension; conservative, non-surgical interventions, like dietary modifications, exercise, headache hygiene and of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors or alternatives like topiramate should be tried first.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a severe headache for the past 10 hours that started when she woke up in the morning. The patient states that she had a milder headache 4 days ago. She has no prior history of headaches. She has now developed, in addition to a persistent headache, neck stiffness and sensitivity to light. She has a past medical history of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. She takes no medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mmHg. The patient is in distress secondary to pain. She is alert and oriented. She has pain with passive knee extension when lying supine with her hips flexed at 90°. Fundoscopy, serum leukocyte count, and CT of the head without contrast are normal. Which of the following additional findings would most likely be present upon further evaluation?
questions.solution:
This patient, with Ehlers-Danlos, who presents with a severe headache, signs of meningeal irritation and a prior sentinel headache most likely has a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). A non-contrast computerized tomography (CT) of the head was performed to look for traumatic and non-traumatic etiologies and was negative. In the absence of acute radiographic findings of hemorrhage, if the index of suspicion for SAH is high, a diagnostic lumbar puncture may be confirmatory, if it reveals an elevated red blood cell count and xanthochromia.           

CT imaging loses sensitivity for SAH as early as six hours following aneurysmal rupture but xanthochromia may persist for up to 3-4 weeks. Xanthochromia is a yellow discoloration of the CSF from elevated bilirubin that results from hemoglobin breakdown.        

Once the diagnosis of SAH is confirmed, patients can have further imaging with CT angiogram or digital subtraction angiography to differentiate between aneurysmal and non-aneurysmal causes of non-traumatic SAH. Saccular or berry aneurysms within the Circle of Willis are most common to rupture. Individuals with connective tissue disease, like Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, are at an increased risk of aneurysmal formation.   

Option Analysis

✅ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) xanthochromia:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Dilated, unresponsive pupils:
Incorrect: Mydriasis (dilated pupils) may occur due to impending brain herniation from increased intracranial pressure which would be associated with significantly altered mental status and Cushing triad of hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respirations indicating increased intracranial pressure. This patient has normal vital signs and a normal fundoscopic examination. 
❌ A shortened partial thromboplastin time (PTT):
Incorrect: This patient presents with signs of subarachnoid hemorrhage. In this patient it is likely due to underlying Ehlers Danlos syndrome. SAH may also be caused by coagulopathy, in which case bleeding from impaired clotting function will prolong, and not shorten the partial thromboplastin time. 
❌ Irregularly irregular rhythm on electrocardiography (ECG):
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation, as evidenced by an irregularly irregular rhythm on heart monitoring, is a risk factor for clot formation and subsequent ischemic stroke. This patient presents with signs and symptoms consistent with SAH. Ehlers-danlos syndrome is the most probable cause in this patient. 
❌ Petechial rash:
Incorrect: Patients with Bacterial meningitis can present with headache, nuchal rigidity, and a skin rash. The absence of fever and a normal serum white blood cell count makes this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a headache. The patient reports episodic migraines with aura since adolescence. Today, a sudden, intense headache developed, described as the “worst of my life.” Past medical history includes gastroesophageal reflux. Medications include omeprazole, amitriptyline, and rizatriptan as needed. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 188/85 mmHg. She appears alert but irritable, with noted photophobia and nuchal rigidity. There is drift in the right upper extremity. Which of the following historical findings most strongly suggests the need for neuroimaging?
questions.solution:
This patient with a long history of primary headaches now presents with a thunderclap headache, raising concern for secondary causes such as subarachnoid hemorrhage. A thunderclap headache is characterized by sudden-onset, severe pain, unlike the gradually progressive pain typical of migraine, and neuroimaging is warranted.

Primary headaches (e.g., migraine, tension-type headaches) occur without an underlying structural or systemic condition. In contrast, secondary headaches result from an identifiable disease process, such as meningitis or subarachnoid hemorrhage. Neuroimaging is rarely indicated for primary headaches but should be performed in patients with features suggestive of a secondary headache, typically starting with a non-contrast CT of the brain.

History and physical examination can help distinguish primary from secondary headache disorders by identifying red flags. These concerning features are summarized by the SNNOOP10 mnemonic, which includes:

  •    Systemic symptoms (such as fever or weight loss)
  •    Neurological deficits   Neoplasm (known history of cancer)
  •    Onset sudden (thunderclap headache) 
  •    Onset after age 50
The additional ten "p"s include:
  •    Pattern change in headache
  •    Positional headache (worsening with changes in posture)
  •    headache Precipitated by Valsalva maneuvers (such as coughing or sneezing)
  •    Papilledema
  •    Progressive worsening of headache 
  •    Pregnancy
  •    Painful eye with autonomic features
  •    Posttraumatic headache 
  •    Pathology of the immune system (such as HIV or immunosuppressive therapy) 
  •    Painkiller overuse (suggesting medication-overuse headache)

Option Analysis

✅ Onset and intensity of headache:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of headaches:
Incorrect: A history of stable, recurrent migraines does not warrant neuroimaging. However, a sudden change in the character or severity of the headache, especially in the setting of new focal neurological findings, requires further evaluation with imaging.
❌ Use of over-the-counter analgesics:
Incorrect: Chronic use of over-the-counter analgesics increases the risk of medication overuse headache. However, this patient’s sudden change in headache accompanied by focal neurological deficits suggests a more serious etiology.
❌ Family history of meningioma:
Incorrect: Neuroimaging is not indicated for patients with a long-standing, stable pattern of migraine headache, even in the setting of a family history of a benign intracranial mass. Neuroimaging should be considered for patients with a sudden change in headache presentation or pattern, especially when accompanied by focal neurological deficits.
❌ Age:
Incorrect: While age over 50 is considered a risk factor for secondary causes of headache, this individual is only 41. In the absence of other concerning features, age alone would not necessitate neuroimaging.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a headache for six months. There have been intermittent episodes of severe, unilateral head pain behind the right eye, lasting as brief as 15 minutes to 3 hours. The episodes occur either every other day or multiple times per day. Nausea is present, and vomiting occurred once today. Medical history is unremarkable, and no medication is taken. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 128/72 mmHg. The patient appears restless and agitated and is squinting. There is ptosis and miosis of the right eye, which appears injected and tearing. Motor strength and reflexes are normal. Which of the following will provide the diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for the brain

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of cluster headache, a primary headache disorder characterized by severe, unilateral orbital or temporal pain accompanied by ipsilateral autonomic symptoms such as ptosis, miosis, conjunctival injection, and lacrimation. The diagnosis can be made using clinical criteria alone when the presentation is typical, and no red flag features are present.

Primary headache disorders include migraine, tension-type headache, and the trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias such as cluster headache. These conditions can usually be diagnosed based on a careful history and physical examination. In patients without red flag features, further diagnostic testing is often unnecessary.

However, when headache presents with warning signs such as new neurologic deficits, fever, sudden onset headache with thunderclap quality, altered mental status, or signs of increased intracranial pressure, a secondary cause should be suspected. These may include conditions such as giant cell arteritis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, meningitis, cerebral venous sinus thrombosis, or idiopathic intracranial hypertension. In such cases, further workup with neuroimaging, cerebrospinal fluid analysis, or laboratory testing is required to confirm the diagnosis and guide management.   

Option Analysis

✅ Clinical criteria:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis:
Incorrect: CSF analysis is used to evaluate for secondary causes of headache, such as meningitis or subarachnoid hemorrhage. It is not indicated in the evaluation of a typical cluster headache.
❌ Inflammatory markers:
Incorrect: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein are primarily useful in evaluating conditions like giant cell arteritis. They do not aid in the diagnosis of cluster headache.
❌ Temporal artery biopsy:
Incorrect: Temporal artery biopsy is used to diagnose giant cell arteritis, which typically affects adults over 50 and presents with jaw claudication and visual symptoms. This patient’s age and symptom pattern are more consistent with cluster headache, which is diagnosed clinically.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for the brain:
Incorrect: MRI may be used to rule out structural causes of headaches when red flag features are present. However, without neurologic deficits or atypical features, imaging is not necessary for diagnosing a typical cluster headache.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman arrives at the outpatient neurologist for a pulsatile headache that is worse in the morning. She also has experienced occasional episodes of vomiting. She has no significant past medical history, and she does not take any medication. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 122/70 mmHg, pulse is 68/min., and body mass index is 25 kg/m2. Fundoscopic examination reveals bilateral papilledema. There is no neck stiffness or cranial nerve deficits. Sensation and strength are intact in all extremities. The cardiovascular, pulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. After appropriate workup, the patient is diagnosed with idiopathic intracranial hypertension. She is started on a medication that inhibits carbonic anhydrase. Which of the following laboratory findings best characterizes the adverse effects of this medication?
questions.solution:
The patient was prescribed a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (CAI) for management of idiopathic intracranial hypertension.    

In the kidneys, CAIs inhibit the carbonic anhydrase enzyme located in the proximal convoluted tubule. These medications increase the amount of bicarbonate, sodium, and water being excreted in the urine. Since CAIs decrease bicarbonate reabsorption, more bicarbonate remains in the urine, resulting in urine alkalinization. Of note, the alkaline urine predisposes patients to forming calcium phosphate renal stones. In contrast, serum bicarbonate concentration decreases, resulting in metabolic acidosis.    

Patients taking CAIs will also develop hypokalemia. This is since CAIs cause increased amounts of urine sodium to reach the collecting duct, where more sodium leads to more potassium excretion into the urine. In addition, patients can develop hyperchloremia since the body compensates for reduced serum bicarbonate levels by releasing chloride from the cells into the blood.  

At high doses, patients may develop neurological side effects such as drowsiness and paresthesias.  

Lastly, CAIs are contraindicated in patients with liver cirrhosis since individuals with liver damage have difficulty removing ammonia from the blood. CAIs further decrease urinary excretion of ammonia, potentially causing hyperammonemia and hepatic encephalopathy.  



Option Analysis

❌  Serum Bicarbonate  Serum Potassium  Urine pH  ↓  ↓  ↓ :
Incorrect: The patient was started on a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (e.g. acetazolamide) for treatment of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). The medication prevents bicarbonate reabsorption from the urine. This results in a low serum bicarbonate level and high urine pH, since bicarbonate is an alkaline substance. 
✅  Serum Bicarbonate  Serum Potassium  Urine pH  ↓  ↓  ↑:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Serum Bicarbonate  Serum Potassium  Urine pH  ↓  ↑ ↑ :
Incorrect: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g. acetazolamide) increase urine bicarbonate excretion. This causes serum bicarbonate to decrease and urine pH to increase, since bicarbonate is an alkaline substance. However, this medication class would also cause hypokalemia as an adverse effect. 
❌  Serum Bicarbonate  Serum Potassium  Urine pH  ↑ ↓  ↓ :
Incorrect: The patient was started on a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (e.g. acetazolamide) for treatment of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). The medication reduces bicarbonate absorption in the proximal convoluted tubule, thus decreasing serum bicarbonate levels. 
❌  Serum Bicarbonate  Serum Potassium  Urine pH  ↑  ↑  ↑ :
Incorrect: The patient was started on a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (e.g. acetazolamide) for treatment of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). The medication reduces bicarbonate absorption in the proximal convoluted tubule, thus decreasing serum bicarbonate levels. Moreover, the medication would cause hypokalemia as an adverse effect.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of a recurrent, throbbing headache. The headache occurs over the left side of her head and is associated with nausea, photophobia, and vomiting without an associated aura. The patient has been using over-the-counter acetaminophen without relief from her symptoms. The headache is often triggered by eating chocolate and relieved by resting in a dark, quiet room. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for trigeminal neuralgia in the patient’s father. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the most appropriate treatment option for this patient during these episodes?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache associated with photophobia, nausea, and vomiting, consistent with migraine without aura. Triptans are recommended in patients who have moderate-to-severe migraine headaches or are unresponsive to over-the-counter analgesics.

Triptans function as agonists at 5-HT1B and 5HT1D serotonin receptors to prevent vasoactive peptide release and reduce trigeminal nerve activation via vasoconstriction. These medications are also used as a first-line treatment option for managing acute cluster headaches. Examples include sumatriptan and zolmitriptan.

Side effects of triptans include pain or burning at the injection site when administered subcutaneously and paresthesias, fatigue,  and dizziness when administered orally. Since triptans are known to induce vasoconstriction, they can also raise blood pressure resulting in coronary vasospasm and angina. Triptans are contraindicated in patients with underlying hypertension, coronary artery disease, prinzmetal angina, and peripheral vascular disease. When used with other serotonin receptor agonists, Triptans can induce serotonin syndrome. Patients who have recently been given ergot alkaloids or other serotonin agonists should avoid triptans for at least 24 hours.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Calcitonin gene-related peptide receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: Erenumab is a human monoclonal antibody that antagonizes calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor function. It is approved as a preventive treatment for migraine, but it is not effective in the management of treating acute migraine.  
✅ 5-HT1B/1D agonist:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Beta-blocker:
Incorrect: Beta-blockers, such as propranolol, can be used for prophylaxis in managing migraines. It is not an abortive agent.  
❌ Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor:
Incorrect: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors effectively manage major depressive disorder, not acute migraine.  
❌ D2 receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: Antipsychotic medications such as haloperidol are D2 receptor antagonists used to manage schizophrenia, psychosis, and bipolar disorder. It is not a practical option for the treatment of acute migraine.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a severe, throbbing left-sided headache for the past several hours. The patient has had 2-3 similar headaches over the past 3 months and finds relief when she secludes herself in a dark, quiet room. The patient has not had any over-the-counter medications for these headaches. She has a past medical history of peptic ulcer disease. Vital signs are within normal limits and physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following medications is indicated for treatment of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with symptoms of a migraine. First-line treatments for migraines include triptans, acetaminophen, and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen. The patient's medical history of peptic ulcer bleeding is a contraindication to NSAID use, making acetaminophen the best medication to administer in this context.

Acetaminophen works by reversibly inhibiting COX in the central nervous system, thereby decreasing production of the prostaglandins that cause fever and pain. It is important to note that acetaminophen is not considered a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) because it does not inhibit COX peripherally. Unlike NSAIDs, acetaminophen lacks anti-inflammatory activity. Acetaminophen is a preferred medication in the treatment of fever and pain in individuals with bleeding disorders, peptic ulcers, and individuals allergic to aspirin.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Acetaminophen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Codeine:
Incorrect: Opioids, such as codeine, are not effective for acute migraine treatment. In addition, the use of opioids is complicated by their potential for tolerance, addiction, and overdose.   
❌ Ketorolac:
Incorrect: Ketorolac is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that would be contraindicated in this patient with a recent history of peptic ulcer bleeding, especially when equally effective alternatives are available.   
❌ Ibuprofen:
Incorrect: Ibuprofen is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that would be contraindicated in this patient given a history of peptic ulcer bleeding, especially when equally effective alternatives are available.   
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is a beta-blocker that is an effective treatment for the prevention (prophylactic) of migraines. Other prophylactic medications include topiramate, tricyclics, and valproate. However, it would not be effective for acute pain relief.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents to the emergency department (ED) with five hours of headache, nausea, and vomiting. The headache is pounding, located on the left side of the head, and is associated with photophobia. Past medical history includes liver cirrhosis, chronic kidney disease, chronic migraines, and peptic ulcer disease. Current medications include diltiazem, lactulose, pantoprazole, and sumatriptan. While in the ED she is given intravenous diphenhydramine and dexamethasone. Which of the following medications should also be given to treat this patient’s migraine-related nausea?
questions.solution:
Migraines are frequently associated with nausea, which is thought to be secondary to a transitory gastroparesis-like state. Metoclopramide is the classically used anti-dopaminergic for nausea related to migraines, but other agents with anti-dopaminergic activity, such as prochlorperazine and promethazine also work very well. In contrast, aprepitant, dronabinol, and meclizine are not particularly effective in treating nausea related to severe migraines. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., ibuprofen, indomethacin, naproxen) are frequently used to abort migraines, but have many contraindications (e.g., renal failure, gastroduodenal ulcers).  

Prochlorperazine primarily blocks D2 dopamine receptors in the chemoreceptor trigger zone in the central nervous system (CNS). It also inhibits M1 and H1 receptors in the CNS and thus can cause side effects including sedation, constipation, and urinary retention. Like other anti-dopaminergic agents, prochlorperazine needs to be used cautiously in patients on antipsychotics, as concomitant use can precipitate tardive dyskinesia.

Option Analysis

❌ Aprepitant:
Incorrect: Aprepitant is a neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist and is usually reserved for nausea and vomiting related to highly emetogenic chemotherapy.
❌ Dronabinol:
Incorrect: Dronabinol activates cannabinoid receptors in the chemoreceptor trigger zone and is used to treat anorexia and nausea in patients with AIDS or those on chemotherapy. It is used long-term or as a prophylactic agent and is not very effective for quick relief of nausea related to migraines.
❌ Indomethacin:
Incorrect: This patient has chronic kidney disease, liver cirrhosis, and peptic ulcer disease, all of which are relative contraindications to the use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
❌ Meclizine:
Incorrect: Meclizine is an antihistamine that acts in the vestibular apparatus to reduce nausea from vertigo or motion sickness. In contrast, it is not as effective in treating nausea related to migraines.
✅ Prochlorperazine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
